content.description: A student is examining two nails, labeled <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>. When Nail <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi> </math> is connected to a magnet, it can pick up iron filings, but drops roughly half of them when the magnet is removed. When Nail <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is connected to a magnet, it also picks up iron filings, but it loses all of them when the magnet is removed.
content.question:
Which of the following provides a correct description of the types of materials in these nails and provides valid reasoning?

Nail <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>
 Nail <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>
 Reason

A
 Ferromagnetic
 Ferromagnetic
 Both materials become magnetized in the presence of a magnet.

B
 Ferromagnetic
 Paramagnetic
 A ferromagnetic material retains some of the strength of the magnetic field after the magnet is removed. A paramagnetic material loses all its magnetic field strength when the magnet is removed.

C
 Paramagnetic
 Ferromagnetic
 A paramagnetic material retains some of the strength of the magnetic field after the magnet is removed. A ferromagnetic material loses all its magnetic field strength when the magnet is removed.

D
 Paramagnetic
 Paramagnetic
 Both materials become magnetized and drop some of the iron filings when the magnet is removed.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
